subject: Ethics
title: Thoreau and Nature's Moral Value
description: A quick, practical guide to Thoreau and Nature's Moral Value.

hook.text: A Harvard grad moved to a cabin in the woods for two years just to think about what life really means.

buildup.text: Henry David Thoreau's 1854 book 'Walden' argued that nature wasn't just sceneryâ€”it was a moral teacher.

discovery.text: Thoreau believed wildness held truths that cities buried. 'In wildness is the preservation of the world.'

twist.text: His ideas were ignored in his lifetime. Today, Thoreau is the godfather of the environmental movement.

climax.text: Thoreau's civil disobedience also inspired protesters blocking pipelines and defending old-growth forests.

punchline.text: One cabin, one book. A movement that still echoes.

quiz.question: What did Thoreau argue about nature in 'Walden'?
options: Nature is a moral teacher and wildness preserves the world
Nature is dangerous and should be conquered by civilization
Nature is only valuable for its economic resources
